customData.content: 33-year-old male presented to the Emergency Department with severe abdominal pain for five days. Pain located in the left flank, radiated to the back, associated with difficult evacuation and one episode of bloody vomiting. Physical examination revealed a large abdominal mass occupying from the epigastrium to the hypogastrium, in addition to both flanks, slightly lateralized to the left, with well-defined margins, fibroelastic consistency, mobile, slightly tense and painful on palpation.

HPI.summary: 33-year-old male presented to the Emergency Department with severe abdominal pain for five days.

physical_exam.location: Epigastrium to hypogastrium, both flanks, slightly lateralized to the left
physical_exam.characteristics: Well-defined margins, fibroelastic consistency, mobile, slightly tense and painful on palpation

customData.content: No signs of peritonitis. Hemoglobin level of 10.5g/dL (reference range: 14–18 g/dL). Prothrombin time, partial thromboplastine time and INR (International Normalized Ratio) were slightly increased. Carcinoembryonic Antigen (CEA) level was 0,52ng/mL (reference range: <3,5ng/dL) and Carbohydrate Antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9) was 3,92U/mL (reference range: <35U/mL).

CT scan exhibited a large cystic lesion with a solid component in the posterior region, measuring 17.8 x 16 x 10.9 cm, located mainly in the mesogastrium, causing compression of intestinal loops. The lesion has a close relation with the Treitz ligament and middle colic vessels, suggesting a mesenteric cyst.

imaging.finding: Large cystic lesion with a solid component in the posterior region, measuring 17.8 x 16 x 10.9 cm, located mainly in the mesogastrium, causing compression of intestinal loops. The lesion has a close relation with the Treitz ligament and middle colic vessels

customData.content: Resection of the cystic lesion was indicated. Surgical approach through median incision revealed a large cyst with peritoneum and small bowel adhesions.

procedures.name: Resection
procedures.description: Resection of the cystic lesion was indicated. Surgical approach through median incision revealed a large cyst with peritoneum and small bowel adhesions.

customData.content: Anterior wall of the cyst was incised, and 1.5L of dark brown fluid was drained and sent for analysis. The posterior wall of the cyst was firmly connected to the root of the mesentery, adjacent to the middle colic vessels, making resection unsafe, so cystic marsupialization was performed.

procedures.name: Drainage
procedures.description: 1.5L of dark brown fluid was drained and sent for analysis

customData.content: Analysis of the cyst fluid showed hypocellular cytological preparations with rare lymphocytes and histiocytes on a sero-hemorrhagic background.
Patient discharged three days after the procedure without complications. Total operative time was 125 minutes.

Histopathological examination of the cyst capsule revealed a dense fibrous connective wall with indistinct epithelial lining, frequent thin-walled congested vessels, and lymphocytic inflammatory process with associated hemosiderophages. No epithelial elements or cytological signs of malignancy were identified. Cyst wall constituted by dense fibrous connective tissue, containing (a) lymphomononuclear inflammatory infiltrate permeating congested thin-walled blood vessels and (b) hemorrhagic foci and accumulations of hemosiderophages. Findings were consistent with benign cystic mesothelioma of the mesentery.

imaging.impression: benign cystic mesothelioma of the mesentery

customData.content: At a post-operative follow up period 3 months, there were no significant symptoms and no clinical evidence of recurrence.

data.content: Histopathological examination reveals benign cystic mesothelioma
